animalOfTheDay.name: woolly mammoth
facts: Permafrost-preserved mammoths provide DNA for de-extinction projects.
Woolly mammoths had fur up to 3 ft long and 4-inch fat layers for insulation.
Their curved tusks measured 16 ft – used for clearing snow to reach grass.
Mammoths survived on Wrangel Island until 1650 BCE – contemporary with Egyptian pyramids.

calendar.name: wasp
facts: Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.
Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.
Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.
Fig wasps co-evolved with figs – each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.

calendar.name: water buffalo
facts: Water buffaloes have wide-splayed hooves preventing sinking in mud.
Domesticated for 5,000 years, they provide more milk than dairy cows in some regions.
Wild water buffaloes are endangered; only 3,400 remain in fragmented habitats.
They wallow in water to cool down and deter biting insects.

calendar.name: wild boar
facts: Wild boars have razor-sharp tusks that regrow continuously.
They create 'boar baths' – mud wallows that cool and remove parasites.
Sows build 'farrowing nests' of woven grass before giving birth.
Boars run 30 mph and jump 5-ft fences.

calendar.name: wild dog
facts: African wild dogs vote to hunt via sneezing – more sneezes trigger departures.
They regurgitate food for pups, elders, and injured pack members.
Packs hold territories up to 900 square miles.
Wild dogs have mottled coats unique to each individual.

calendar.name: wombat
facts: They dig complex burrows with multiple entrances and sleeping chambers.
Wombat rear hides have cartilage plates – blocking dingo bites when fleeing to tunnels.
They can run 25 mph despite stubby legs.
Wombats produce cube-shaped feces – unique among animals – to prevent rolling.

calendar.name: woodpecker
facts: Woodpeckers have shock-absorbing skulls and compressible brain cases.
Their tongues wrap around skulls to cushion brains during pecking.
Pileated woodpeckers create rectangular holes in trees searching for ants.
Acorn woodpeckers drill thousands of holes to store acorns – 'granary trees'.

calendar.name: woolly mammoth
facts: Woolly mammoths had fur up to 3 ft long and 4-inch fat layers for insulation.
Their curved tusks measured 16 ft – used for clearing snow to reach grass.
Mammoths survived on Wrangel Island until 1650 BCE – contemporary with Egyptian pyramids.
Permafrost-preserved mammoths provide DNA for de-extinction projects.

randomAnimals.name: basset hound
facts: Basset hounds have the second-best sense of smell among all dog breeds.
Their long ears help sweep scents from the ground toward their nose.
They were originally bred in France for hunting small game.
Their short legs and long body make them excellent at following trails slowly.

randomAnimals.name: yak
facts: Yaks survive at 20,000 ft – lungs and hearts 3x larger than cattle.
They grunt instead of mooing; 'yak' mimics their guttural sounds.
Yak milk is rich in butterfat – churned into butter tea in Tibet.
Their dung is dried and burned as fuel in treeless Himalayan regions.

randomAnimals.name: fennec fox
facts: No facts available.
